Description: Light blue all over. Exhibits strong sexual dimorphism: females have wide black bands, males' bands are orange.

Blue Angelfish has an overall aqua hue with a yellow shimmer and yellow edges on the fins and scales. The Blue Angelfish does not have the striking blue crown or other blue highlights of the Queen Angelfish. This species has been known to reproduce with the Queen Angelfish, making a half breed that looks like a mixture between the two species.
Darkly hued with yellow stripes.
Juveniles are black with blue-white spiraling; adults are blue with yellow stripes, accented with white and black and a blue mask. Will easily be the dominant angelfish if housed with other angels.
Juveniles are black with 3 yellow vertically running stripes, may also display blue on pelvic fins. Adults lard black with white vertical stripes.
Light grey with dark spots and bluish/grey mask over face. Closely related to French Angelfish.
An ashen white angel with thick black bands and spots, it is a rare find within the aquarium trade.
Blue with yellow splotch-like marking on side.
Grey towards the face, becoming a navy blue towards the caudal fin with striking iridescent blue accents throughout.

Common name: Majestic angelfish or blue girdled angelfish
Description: Yellow dorsal and caudal fins connecting to "saddal" with dark blue dots. Dark blue underside and anal fin. Electric blue separating yellow and dark blue.
Very dark blue with yellow caudal fin and distinctive white stripe.

Common name: Personifer angelfish or Queensland yellowtail angelfish

Description: Tan coloured with yellow caudal fin and neon blue outlined fins. This species has been known to reproduce with the Blue Angelfish, making a half breed that looks like a mixture between the two species.
Orange and blue striped with dark blue dorsal fin and lemon yellow caudal fin.

Black and tan striped back with yellow blaze beginning at the mouth and tapering off towards the centre of the side, with light blueish grey underside. Has distinctively shaped tail resembling that of a swallow.
White fish with vertical black stripes that change to yellow at the belly
Reddish body with blue back and orange fins. A shy fish that prefers multiple hiding locations.
Blue colored body with an orange yellow head.
Tan coloured body with vertical brown stripes and large distinctive black splotch covering the back of the fish, including the caudal fin.
Vivid orange-red with vertical black stripes and blue patches toward the end of the dorsal and anal fins.
Anterior is gray to pearly white with orange accent around eye, posterior is deep black.
Completely lemon yellow, with a brown marking around the eye.

Centropyge type species. Overall black with an elongate vertical black blotch on the middle of the upper sides. When small, mainly black with a white bar. Dorsal and anal fins with submarginal blue line; most of the pelvic and the anterior portion of the anal fin yellow. Caudal fin with submarginal blue line.
Bright yellow with distinctive dark semicircle by operculum.
Dark blue with golden yellow blaze running from the face down the dorsal fin, with a colourless caudal fin.
Similarly coloured to the Coral Beauty, but with a blue body and reddish fins.
Tan coloured body with dark spots and a reddish tint around the anal fin.
The tips of the spines of the dorsal fin are black, and it may have a dark red cap above the eyes. There is a variant with a uniformly pale body except for the frontal part.
Deep black to tan fish with blue spots throughout.
Dark tan with horizontal blue stripes that are not particularly straight. The caudal fin has more of these stripes, and they radiate from the base of the fin out to the tips.
Blue iridescent body with distinctive black topside that is interrupted by small vertical blue stripes.
Chocolate brown with light yellow horizontal stripes. Similar in patterning to C. argus (with exception to the coloration).
Very striking black and white checkerboard pattern all over, with very long tapering nose.
Sports a large, hinged mouth and is tan with little spots. Has brown triangle shaped markings down the spine.
Gorgeous pure white fish with black spots and a distinctive "hump" on the head, leading to a popular common name, "Humpback Grouper".
Large fish with classic Bass body, Silvery in colour with vertical tan stripes and a blue underside.
Very similar to C. miniatus, but the caudal fin is dark.
Silver back changing to red around the underside, darkening toward the caudal fin, which is lyre-shaped with neon green edging.
Dark black fish with many light green spots all over body, increasing in number toward the posterior.
Purple with a black mask beginning at the mouth and ending at the base of the dorsal fin.
Entirely navy blue with white edging of the dorsal fin.

Purple head and anterior, abruptly changing to yellow about halfway down the body. Has black marking through eye and another on the dorsal fin. Do not confuse with the Brazilian Gramma or the Bicolor Dottyback.
Very similar to the royal gramma, however the change from purple to yellow occurs farther down the body and the black markings are absent.
Bright lemon yellow with peach fringing of the dorsal fin and around the eye.
Brown with generally random black markings resembling a rotting leaf.
Dark black body completely edged by distinctive yellow and orange.
Silver with black fins and a black stripe across the face.
Brown checkered body with distinctive yellow frills on head.
Characterized by the striking contrast of a blue head and upper torso followed by a yellow orange lower torso.
Yellow bodied with bright blue mask and dark black line running from the eye to the caudal fin.
Black with lighter patch over caudal fin. Very distinctive swallowtail caudal fin.
Similarly shaped to M. bundoon, but canary yellow.
Gray with black splotches, and a yellow mask. Shaped more like hawkfish than a blenny.
Pale pinkish-grey body with jet-black dorsal and anal fins. Eyes are primarily white, sometimes seen with brown segmentation.
Tan and brown striped and spotted with iridescence. Requires Mature Tank.
Although often seen yellow, this fish has the ability to change its color to match the surroundings. It has a very distinctive swallowtail shaped caudal fin.
Mottled tan, white, and black covering the body and fins.
Black to grayish yellow with red patch over mouth.
Sky blue anterior fading to yellow towards the tail, with a black stripe running the eye to the base of the caudal fin.
Very similar to Salarias fasciatus but slightly darker and with a much larger dorsal fin.
Drab tan all over with dark spot at the base of the caudal fin and a light yellow line through eye.
The top half of this fish is black towards the front and fades to white closer to the tail. The bottom half is white with two distinctive black spots right under the pectoral fins.
Not actually a blenny but from closely related family Pholidichthys. Juvenile has black eel-shaped body with a distinctive white stripe running down the body. Adults are yellow and black striped.
Tan with dark speckles and brown spots at the base of the caudal fin.
Grayish tan with very distinctive "horns" near the eyes and under the caudal fin.
Dark navy blue with iridescent "scribbling" and spots.
Tan with a brown mask over eyes and other over mouth. Also has yellow markings on the pectoral and dorsal fins.
Tan with slightly darker spots throughout and very conspicuous spines that lay flat against the body. When puffed up, the spikes stand up and make the fish completely inedible.
White and covered in small black spots.
Cream, with reddish purple topside and underside, and yellow on the caudal fin.
Tan with giraffe-like spots and dark brown markings that resemble saddles over the back. Has distinctive bright green eyes.
Usually seen as a juvenile, bright yellow with little black spots. When it reaches maturity it is gray with yellow lines and pink lips.
Silver with black edged gold stripes, a long nose, and a black eyespot on the dorsal fin.
Sometimes referred to as the "Poor Man's Moorish Idol" because of the resemblance to one. White and black striped with yellow caudal fin and a dorsal fin that forms a long, thin banner.
From the pectoral fins forward, black above the eye and silver below, with an exceptionally mouth. Past the pectoral fins, bright yellow with an eyespot on the anal fin.
Very distinctive and complexly colored. Is mostly yellow with a darker saddle and a black and white mask.
White with black stripes that form chevrons on the side and a bright red patch on the posterior.
White with fuzzy black stripes and a yellow posterior. Also has a black line through the eye.
Completely yellow with the exception of black stripes at the base of the caudal fin and through the eye, and an eyespot directly below the dorsal fin.
Very similar to C. unimaculatus, but with scales that are brighter than the body, forming a lattice-like pattern, and lacking the eyespot.
Silver with two dark saddles over the body (plus a dark mask) and yellow dorsal and caudal fins.
Often confused with C. ulietensis, but easily distinguished. The saddles are wedge shaped rather than stripes and do not reach the underside. Overall more yellow coloring.
White anterior with thin black stripes at 45 and 120 degree angles from the head. Posterior is yellow, but with a black wedge shape where the stripes meet the yellow coloring.
White with small black spots, a yellow mask, and a black dorsal fin.
Bright lemon yellow with subtle vertical orange stripes and a black splotch behind the eye.
Black and silver striped with very tall fins and many white spots. Wild populations have been decimated, consider captive bred specimens. Banggai Cardinalfish are mouthbrooders.
Body completely covered in horizontal yellow and black stripes, with red fins.
Bright red with black spots at the base of the caudal fin, under the second dorsal fin, and on the operculum.
Light yellow with iridescent yellow horizontal stripes.
A thin, dark vertical 'waistband' with scattered dark spots toward the tail.

This fish displays three distinct color bands: the first, stretching from the nose to base of the first dorsal fin, is a tannish peach. The second, a thin band which runs down the center of the fish, is chocolate brown, and the posterior of the fish is white with brown spots.
Almost identical to A. nigrofasticus, but with blue eyes.
Yellow body with a black stripe (ring) at the base of the caudal fin and iridescent blue streaks across the eye.
Mostly silver, but with a large patch of yellow around the caudal fin and a distinct black line on the operculum.
Yellowish with bright blue iridescent pelvic fins and a distinct black bar at the base of the caudal fin.
Bright blue all over, although lighter toward the front.
Completely black. Despite the name, this is actually a chromis, in fact, it is the chromis.
Generally bluish green, but some specimens may be spring green.
Completely black from the middle of the dorsal fin to the nose, completely white from the middle of the dorsal fin to the end of the caudal fin.
Dark navy blue with bright yellow spot that covers the dorsal fin and much of the posterior.
Dark chocolate brown, slightly lighter around the pectoral fins.
Rather drab tannish-orange throughout.
Similar to half and half chromis, but there is more black.
Dark orange body becoming black towards the caudal fin, with a bright white stripe running from the front of the dorsal fin to the pectoral fins and golden colored fins.
Black or dark brown with bright yellow finnage and two thick white stripes running perpendicular to the body.
Bright orange or yellow body with white stripes. Fins are orange, rimmed with black. A. ocellaris from northern Australia are black.
Maroon to bright red with three very thin white stripes.
Nearly identical to A. ocellaris, but the white stripes are edged with black.
Pink to orange body with one white stripe over the operculum and another running from the tip of the snout, along the back to the dorsal fin. All fins are white.
Bright red with a single white stripe running from the front of the dorsal fin to the bottom of the head.
Similar to A. ocellaris and percula, but the second stripe does not extend the full with of the body and instead resembles a saddle.
Black or dark brown body from above the pectoral fin, yellow below. Has two white stripes, the second resembling that of A. polymnus.
A beautiful fish with neon blue on its body and a gold underside and caudal fin. Easy to care for and does best on a good diet. Fairly aggressive so choose tankmates carefully.
An orange tail indicates breeding success. The males have orange on their tails while the females do not. This fish is hardy and aggressive.
also known as the three spot damsel, this fish is easy to care for, but is also very aggressive. The fish is black except for three distinct white spots that fade as the fish ages.
This striking blue damsel is one of the most popular beginner fish. Like other damsels, it is very hardy, and very aggressive when mature.
The four stripe damsel is a perfect beginner marine fish as it is very hardy. This fish is highly territorial and is best suited for a semi-aggressive to aggressive tank.
These are temperate fish and require cooler water. They are much larger than most other damsels.
Among the largest and most aggressive Damsels
Turns brown, and becomes highly territorial as it ages
The marginated damsel is noted for blue fins as well as the yellow head and white body. This fish is hardy like most damsels and is also highly aggressive when mature.

This damselfish is somewhat a little more delicate than other. It does best in small groups in large tanks with good water quality and an SG of 1.026. Feed on a good diet for best results. Fairly peaceful.
Highly aggressive and territorial. Will harass fish many times its size. Best kept in an aggressive/semi-aggressive tank.

the two stripe damsel is a very hardy fish. This fish is perfect for the beginner marine aquarist, as it can tolerate substandard water quality. This fish is highly aggressive, and requires many hiding places.

The yellowtail damsel possess an all blue body with a striking yellow tail. This damsel is a good beginner fish as it is very hardy and can tolerate substandard water quality. This damsel is also less aggressive than some other damsel species.

Common name: Blue ribbon eel, black ribbon eel

Description: Can be kept with fish too small to swallow
A fish eater that will eat anything it can fit in its mouth. When available is typically quite expensive
Rarely available, among the smallest of the moray eels

These fish should only be kept in fish-only tanks as any small invertebrates will be looked on as food. Keep with fish large enough not to be eaten. Feed on a diet of whitefish, cockles, cod roe, haddock and frozen foods.
Requires a 180-gallon tank with tight fitting lid. Compatible with rays, sharks, and other large fish.
A pebble-tooth moray that generally eats crustaceans and similar. Safer in reef aquariums than other species but be prepared to remove it in case it starts to eat desired invertebrates.
NEEDS a very deep substrate (8 inches) and only eats plankton, when housing multiple make sure that there is enough space for each eels to be far enough away from each other
Requires at least six in of substrate
One of the easier moray eels to keep, is usually safe with most fish but will eat most invertebrates.
Moderate
Moderate

Reef safe: Will eat shrimp and other invertebrates, will not harm coral:?413?
Description: Moderate:?413?
Has the ability to change color to match its surrounding.

Reef safe: Mostly; can destroy unhealthy Acropora by laying its eggs in the coral's tissue
Description: Similar to Yellow clown goby, but black
A cold water species that doesn't live long at reef temperatures.

Reef safe: Mostly; can destroy unhealthy Acropora by laying its eggs in the coral's tissue

Description: Burrow and sift sand constantly; very good algae eaters
Small burrowing goby with green vertical stripes
A Caribbean cleaner species that sometimes eats larger parasites from other fish.
White fish with pink bands around the body and pink spots on face and fins. One of the most handsome members of the group.
A small goby that can clean like the neon goby but is easily frightened. Often said to 'disappear' in a larger tank, as it never swims out into view.
Also a freshwater and brackish water fish and often sold as Dragon Fish or Dragon Goby
A species of "watchman" or "shrimp" goby that can form a symbiotic relationship with pistol shrimp
A species of "watchman" or "shrimp" goby that will form a symbiotic relationship with the red and white banded pistol shrimp, Alpheus randalli.
Small yellow fish that likes branching corals
A very small goby species with bright colors and a large dorsal fin. Hides in crevices and holes during the day and is nocturnal.
Brown to yellow body with reddish dorsal fin, distinctive white caudal fin, and small semicircular marking behind eye.
Striking red body with black on fin tips and yellow lips.
White with red lattice-like markings resembling a grid. Nose is elongated and tissue between the spines of the dorsal fin is missing.
Bright red with distinctive diamond shaped markings down back, becoming darker towards the topside of body.

Because they live in the open ocean, they are rare in the aquarium trade. They host sharks, rays, and sea turtles[circular reference] and eat food scraps, ectoparasites, and possibly the feces of their host. Juvenile Golden trevally are occasionally sold as Pilot fish. In the picture, the Pilot fish are hosting an Oceanic whitetip shark.
Requires a 30-gallon tank and 3 inches (7.6 cm) substrate. Tank should remain tightly lidded. May eat small shrimp.
Requires a 30-gallon tank and 3 inches (7.6 cm) sand substrate. Tank should remain tightly lidded.
Requires a 30-gallon tank and 5–7 inches (13–18 cm) soft substrate. Tank should remain tightly lidded.
Carnivore; Males 6< stripes on pectoral fin femals >6
Semi-aggressive; carnivore

Resembles royal gramma in coloration. The bicolor pseudochromis is semi-aggressive and will defend its territory against fish several times its size. This fish is fairly hardy, and is a good beginner fish.
Captive bred specimens are sometimes available
Community fish does well in most aquariums. is not nearly as aggressive as other dottybacks.

Common name: Neon pseudochromis, Arabian dottyback or neon dottyback
Description: Captive bred specimens are sometimes available

Common name: Purple stripe pseudochromis or diadema basslet

Description: Large and aggressive for a dottyback
Captive bred species are sometimes available
Captive bred specimens are sometimes available

A generally hardy fish, resembles the orchid dottyback, in that the body is a solid purple (sometimes pink), but is missing the black line/marking through the eye characteristic of orchids. This fish semi-aggressive in a home aquarium.
Despite being eel-like in appearance, Carpet eel-blennies are part of the family pseudochromidae.
they have poisonous spines

Requires a minimum 180 gallon aquarium. Recently purchased individuals can be startled easily by quick movements and loud noises, but they will become quite tame after spending a while in captivity. Unhealthy individuals will become a light grey color and their markings will fade. Occasionally called the Cortez ray and thus misidentified as Urobatis maculatus.

Requires a minimum 180 gallon aquarium and is hardy and attains a small size although rarely available[citation needed]. May be misidentified with Urobatis halleri as that species is occasionally called the Cortez ray.
Requires a minimum 180 gallon aquarium. An occasionally available. A hardy species.
Probably is a hardy species.
Requires a minimum 180 gallon aquarium and readily acclimates to suitable captive environments. It is also readily available in the aquarium trade and will eat any small fish that it can catch.
Requires a minimum 180 gallon aquarium. It is small and well suited for captivity.

Requires a minimum 260 gallon aquarium. It is notorious for doing terribly in aquarium confines. Many individuals never eat and others may die or stop feeding for no apparent reason. Force-feeding shows promise with this species. Not to confused with the Bluespotted stingray Neotrygon kuhlii.

Requires a minimum 260 gallon aquarium and is quite hardy, however it should not be disturbed as it acclimates to aquarium life (which takes around 2–3 days). Provide it with a 5 cm (2 in) deep fine sand bed. Do not confuse this species with the much less hardy Bluespotted ribbontail ray Taeniura lymma.
Requires a minimum 4,200 gallon aquarium as this ray grows to a very large size. It is quite hardy, yet it will devour any fish or invertebrate it can capture.

Requires a minimum 135 gallon aquarium. Is relatively small yet may or may not easily adapt to life in an aquarium. It is best kept in saltwater or brackish systems although they can survive in freshwater.
Requires a minimum 560 gallon aquarium. Well suited to captive life.
Due to its massive proportions, this occasionally available ray should be avoided.
Requires a water temperature of in between 15 °C (59.0 °F) and 25 °C (77.0 °F).
Like other Whiptail stingrays, Pastinachus sephen should be provided with an aquarium containing a sand bed and little aquascaping.
Seems to be well suited to captive life.
Seems to be well suited to captive life although it should be kept at cool temperatures.
Seems to be well suited to captive life.
Requires a minimum 825 gallon aquarium with a 7 cm (2.7 in) deep sand bed and no rockwork. May live for 8 to 10 years in an aquarium.
Requires a minimum 200 gallon aquarium preferably with no aquascaping. Uncommon in the aquarium trade.
Like other guitarfish, it should be kept in an aquarium with a sand bed, much open swimming area, and little rockwork.
Like other guitarfish, it should be kept in an aquarium with a sand bed, much open swimming area, and little rockwork.
Like other guitarfish, it should be kept in an aquarium with a sand bed, much open swimming area, and little rockwork.
Like other guitarfish, it should be kept in an aquarium with a sand bed, much open swimming area, and little rockwork. Also called the Shark ray and the Mud skate.
Requires a minimum 560 gallon aquarium. It is durable but it may have trouble feeding with more agile bony fish tankmates.
Requires a minimum 360 gallon aquarium without any aquascaping. It may consume benthic fishes and its thorns are tangled in nets easily.

Requires a minimum 200 gallon aquarium with little aquascaping and preferably a sand bed. Given such an environment, it will readily adapt to captive life. It can create a cave by lifting the center of its body off the ground to lure in potential prey.

Requires a minimum 300 gallon aquarium with a sand bed, much open swimming area, and little rockwork, and a ledge under which to hide under. Under such conditions, it is somewhat hardy. It is rarely encountered in the aquarium trade.
Is rarely available. Like other guitarfish, it should be kept in an aquarium with a sand bed, much open swimming area, and little rockwork.

Requires a minimum 180 gallon aquarium with a thick sand bed and little to no decoration. Like other species in the genus Torpedo, Large individuals should be carefully handled as they are capable of shocking their owners. This ray should be kept alone.

It is relatively hardy although it usually will only target moving food. Like other species in the genus Torpedo, Large individuals should be carefully handled as they are capable of shocking their owners. It should also be kept in an aquarium with a thick sand bed and little to no decoration. Not to be confused with the Marbled electric ray (Torpedo sinuspersici).

Occasionally available to European hobbyists. It is relatively hardy although it usually will only target moving food. Like other species in the genus Torpedo, Large individuals should be carefully handled as they are capable of shocking their owners. It should also be kept in an aquarium with a thick sand bed and little to no decoration. Not to be confused with the Marbled electric ray (Torpedo marmorata).

Requires a minimum 40 gallon aquarium and is hard to feed. Like the Lesser electric ray, it can be sustained if fed live food including small grass shrimp and annelid worms and should also be provided with a sand bed 6 cm (2.3 in) deep. Also like the Lesser electric ray, it may shock other tankmates, yet it can be kept with others of its own kind. It is rarely encountered in the aquarium trade.

Requires a minimum 70 gallon aquarium. Like the Bullseye electric ray, it can be kept successfully if fed live food such as annelid worms and provided with a layer of sand 6 cm (2.3 in) deep. This ray may shock tankmates although they can be kept with other Lesser electric rays.
Like other rays in the genus Narcine, it is difficult to feed (should be fed annelid worms) and should not be kept with rough surfaced rocks. It can be kept with others of its own kind.
Like other rays in the genus Narcine, it is difficult to feed (should be fed annelid worms) and should not be kept with rough surfaced rocks. It can be kept with others of its own kind.
Also known as the Eilat Sleeper Ray.

Requires a minimum 8,750 gallon aquarium. Like most butterfly rays, it usually does not do well in aquarium confines as it is often hard to feed (thus force feeding shows promise with this species). Also like most butterfly rays, it is an active ray that requires much swimming space like some active sharks. It is rarely available.

Like most butterfly rays, it usually does not do well in aquarium confines as it is often hard to feed (thus force feeding shows promise with this species). Also like most butterfly rays, it is an active ray that requires much swimming space like some active sharks. It is rarely available.

Like most butterfly rays, it usually does not do well in aquarium confines as it is often hard to feed (thus force feeding shows promise with this species). Also like most butterfly rays, it is an active ray that requires much swimming space like some active sharks.

Requires a minimum 4,850 gallon aquarium and if given the space, does quite successfully. Unfortunately, they host large amounts of parasites, requiring quarantine and treatments. May jump out of an open aquarium.
Requires a large system as it is quite large and active.
Requires a large system as it is quite large and active.
Requires a covered, large system as it is quite large, active, and is capable of leaping out of the water. It can be difficult to feed and is very sensitive to trichlorfon.
Requires a large system in which to live in although it does not need to be deep. Is a schooling fish so keeping several of these rays is recommended. It is also quite active.

Reef safe: Not with shrimp or small fish
Not with shrimp or small fish
Not with shrimp or small fish
Not with shrimp or small fish
Not with shrimp or small fish
Not with shrimp or small fish
Not with shrimp or small fish
Not with shrimp or small fish
Not with shrimp or small fish

Description: Highly venomous! Have caused human deaths

Reef safe: Not with shrimp or small fish
Not with shrimp or small fish

Description: ST
Max size: Usually bright yellow, with a particularly long snout.

Description: TR
Max size: Generally yellow, but can also range from tan to dark black.

Description: ST
Max size: Light tan, with some darker specimens.

Description: TM
Max size: Light-colored with dark spots and a large abdomen.

Description: TR
Max size: White with pink (occasionally yellow) knobby protrusions.

Description: TM
Max size: Grayish to tan with short snout and a spiny head.

Description: TR
Max size: Varying colors with dark striped tail.

Description: ST
Max size: Dark colored with lighter belly and white ridges.

Description: TM
Max size: Fuller bodied with a comparatively larger head.

Description: ST
Max size: Similar to H. reidi but much smaller.

Description: TR
Max size: Varying colors with distinctive spines all over body.

Description: Requires a minimum 160 gallon aquarium. Does well in home aquaria and will mate/reproduce in larger aquariums. Sometimes called the Marbled Bamboo Cat Shark.

Requires a minimum 170 gallon aquarium. One of the most common sharks in the North American aquarium trade and does well in home aquaria as it will easily acclimate to captivity and will mate/reproduce in aquariums. Juveniles may take a while to begin feeding if newly acquired. Sometimes called the Banded catshark.

Requires a minimum 260 gallon aquarium. One of the best sharks for home aquaria as it will easily acclimate to captivity and will mate/reproduce in aquariums. Adult males might behave aggressively to other male sharks including male Epualette sharks, and harass females. they aren't very active so a 200-gallon may be acceptable
Requires a minimum 240 gallon aquarium. A sub-tropical species of shark. The most common bullhead shark in the North American aquarium trade.
Requires a minimum 750 gallon aquarium. A sub-tropical species of shark which may be a host to numerous parasites. It will also eat small fish at night.

Requires a minimum 110 gallon aquarium. Active during the night and will try to eat fish housed with them (even ones that are too big to swallow). Two color variants are commonly found in fish stores in the US. Also called the Marbled catshark which is a different species of shark (Atelomycterus macleayi).

Requires a minimum 70 gallon aquarium. Uncommon in the aquarium trade although it is an ideal aquarium species of shark. Commonly confused with the Coral catshark (Atelomycterus marmoratus). Unlike the Coral catshark which is black with white spots and bars, the Marbled catshark is pale with black spots and seven grey saddles and is smaller and more docile.

Requires a minimum 4,800 gallon aquarium. Although durable, the Nurse shark will grow too large for most home aquariums. It is an aggressive feeder which will make it harder for you to feed more reclusive sharks and it can knock over/rearrange aquarium decorations in a small aquarium.

Requires a minimum 6,200 gallon aquarium. The Zebra shark will grow too large for most home aquariums. Sometimes the juveniles of this shark (20–36 cm or 7.9–14.2in long) are sold and require a minimum 100 gallon aquarium. A juvenile Zebra shark is shown in the picture while adults are much larger and have pale coloration with black spots.[circular reference] Also called the Leopard shark which is a different species of shark (Triakis semifasciata).
Requires a minimum 4,500 gallon aquarium. A sub-tropical species of shark and may live a long time in captivity (there are reports of over 20 years).
Requires a minimum 750 gallon aquarium. Markings on the shark fade with age but not completely.

Requires a minimum 1,700 gallon aquarium. A sub-tropical and active species of shark that requires a tank with plenty of room to swim which will do better in circular and oval shaped tanks rather than rectangular ones. It will jump out of uncovered aquariums.

Requires a minimum 1,200 gallon aquarium. A sub-tropical and active species of shark that requires a tank with plenty of room to swim. This shark will do better in circular and oval shaped tanks where they can have an uninterrupted swimming pattern rather than rectangular tanks. It will jump out of uncovered aquariums and it is more likely to suffer from shipping stress than its less active relatives.
Requires a minimum 360 gallon aquarium. Will eat any fish or crustacean housed with it that can be swallowed entirely. Slow-growing when not overfed.
Requires a minimum 170 gallon aquarium. Rare in the North American aquarium trade.

Requires a minimum 3,150 gallon aquarium. The Ornate wobbegong will grow too large for most home aquariums and will eat other elasmobranchs. It is the most common wobbegong in the North American aquarium trade.
Requires a minimum 3,150 gallon aquarium. Although durable, the Spotted wobbegong will grow too large for most home aquariums and will eat other elasmobranchs.

Requires a minimum 110 gallon aquarium. The Northern wobbegong has a passive personality and a small maximum size, and may not eat initially when it has been added to an aquarium and is rarely collected. An aquarist can handle this shark without a lot fear of getting bitten.

Requires a minimum 5,750 gallon aquarium. Easily startled by quick movements and the sudden entry an aquarist in their aquarium which may cause them to jump out of an open tank or hit the walls of their aquarium, leading to death. Must keep swimming in order to breath thus requiring a very large aquarium.
Requires a minimum 8,400 gallon aquarium. Can destroy aquarium decorations when moving through the décor to find food. Often has goiter.

Requires a minimum 2,600 gallon aquarium. Occasionally available and requires expert care. When newly added to an aquarium, the Bonnethead shark will often swim at the surface of the water and lift the front of its head above the surface. When it has settled in, the shark will stop this activity or begin to do it less often. Must keep moving in order to breath.[circular reference]
May take 70-90+ days to hatch. Chiloscyllium shark egg cases are hardy and available. Heterodontus, Scyliorhinidae, and Stegostoma shark egg cases are also available.

Common name: Black snapper, black and white snapper

Description: Passive aggressive. This fish is native to the waters of Hawaii and the South Pacific and therefore requires substantial turbulent flow and circulation to be kept in an aquarium. This fish should only be kept in a six-foot or large aquarium as it requires a large amount of swim room. Very prone to Cryptocaryon irritans
Less aggressive than Achilles or Powder Blue
Bright orange when young and dark olive green when transitioned fully to juvenile.
One of the most aggressive tangs
Very prone to Cryptocaryon irritans. More tolerant of other tangs than most other species.
Very prone to Cryptocaryon irritans.
Similar to the yellow tang in shape and feeding.
One of the larger more aggressive tangs
This fish requires ample swimming room and is difficult to feed.

Common name: Blue jaw trigger / blue throat trigger
Reef safe: Widely regarded as the only reef safe trigger.

Description: A shy reserved fish when first added to the aquarium, comes into its own when it associates itself with the aquarist. Infrequently available
Rarely available
Among the more peaceful of triggers, can usually be kept in a community tank
A large fish that should only be kept in very large aquariums.
A shy reserved fish when first added to the aquarium, comes into its own when it associates itself with the aquarist. Infrequently available
Can only be housed in the largest of marine aquariums
Probably the most aggressive fish kept in marine aquariums. Older specimens should be housed alone.
as the names suggests it is a cleaner fish and will eat some parasites

Reef safe: Generally, yes, but may eat shrimp

Description: Small pink fish with six purple horizontal lines. Sometimes added to help control flatworms or parasitic snail populations. Semi-aggressive and may pick on shy fish.
Golden body with purple horizontal stripes on head.
Yellow body with three or occasionally four black dots on dorsal fins. Require sand bed for sleeping.
